The '''2010 FINA Diving World Cup''' was held in [[Changzhou]], [[Jiangsu]], [[People's Republic of China]] from June 2 to June 6, 2010. It was the 17th [[FINA Diving World Cup]] competition.http://www.espdive.com/Documents/2010FWC.pdf 146 divers from 33 countries and regions competed in this World Cup.http://www.fina.org/H2O/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1443:australias-matthew-mitcham-takes-mens-10m-platform-title-on-last-day&catid=212:diving-world-cup&Itemid=648 The '''2010 FINA Diving World Cup''' is held one year after the [[Diving at the 2009 World Aquatics Championships|2009 FINA Diving World Championships]] which was held in Rome. The “Team Event”, which combines both male and female divers competing side by side, was included for the first time. This event was held on a trial basis.http://www.fina.org/H2O/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=212&Itemid=648{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Summary of Results== *USA won the inaugural "Team Event" *Australia's [[Matthew Mitcham]] won the Men's 10 metre platform competition *China won the remaining seven titles on offer at the 2010 Diving World Cup. == Participating Countries == The number beside each nation represents the number of athletes who competed for each country at the 2010 FINA Diving World Cup. {{div col|colwidth=30em}} {{AUS}} (8)

{{lead too long|date=September 2018}} {{pp-semi-indef}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox civilian attack |title=2012 Benghazi attack |partof= the [[Inter-civil war violence in Libya]] |image=2012 Benghazi attack photo montage.jpg |image_size=300 |caption=From top to bottom, and left to right: President, Vice President updated on situation night of September 11, 2012; President Obama, with Secretary Clinton, delivering statement in the Rose Garden, September 12, 2012; two photographs released through a FOIA request; Secretary Clinton testifying before the Senate Committee on January 23, 2013; portion of "wanted" poster seeking information on the attacks in Benghazi. |location=[[Benghazi]], [[Libya]] |target=United States diplomatic post and CIA annex |date=September 11–12, 2012 |time-begin=21:40 |time-end=04:15 [[Eastern European Time|EET]] |timezone= [[UTC+02:00]] |type=Coordinated attack, armed assault, rioting, [[arson]] |weapons=[[Rocket-propelled grenades]], hand grenades, assault rifles, [[14.5×114mm|14.5 mm]] anti-aircraft machine guns, truck mounted artillery, diesel canisters, [[mortar (weapon)|mortars]] |fatalities= US Ambassador [[J. Christopher Stevens]]; [[United States Foreign Service|USFS]] officer [[Sean Smith (diplomat)|Sean Smith]]; CIA contractors [[Tyrone S. Woods]] and [[Glen Doherty]]; unknown number of Libyan attackers{{clarify|how many?|date=August 2016}} |injuries= 4 Americans, 7 Libyans |susperps=Brigades of the Imprisoned Sheikh Omar Abdul Rahman; [[Ansar al-Sharia (Libya)|Ansar al-Sharia]];{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2012/09/21/libyans-storm-ansar-al-sharia-compound-in-backlash-attack-on-us-consulate/|title=Libyan storm Ansar Al-Sharia compound in backlash after attack on U.S. Consulate|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Fox News Channel |date=September 21, 2012}} [[Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]];Steven Lee Myers, [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/27/world/africa/clinton-cites-clear-link-between-al-qaeda-and-attack-in-libya.html Clinton Suggests Link to Qaeda Offshoot in Deadly Libya Attack] ''[[The New York Times]]'' September 26, 2012 [[Al Qaeda in Iraq]];{{Cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/10/24/world/benghazi-al-qaeda-in-iraq/index.html|title=U.S. Intel believes some Benghazi attackers tied to al Qaeda in Iraq|author1=Suzanne Kelly |author2=Pam Benson |author3=Elise Labott |publisher=CNN |date=October 24, 2012}} [[Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]][http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/02/world/africa/us-libya-benghazi-suspects Paul Cruickshank, Tim Lister, Nic Robertson, and Fran Townsend, "Sources: 3 al Qaeda operatives took part in Benghazi attack"] CNN, May 4, 2013. |perps= }} {{Campaignbox 2011–present Libyan factional fighting}} The '''2012 Benghazi attack''' was a coordinated attack against two United States government facilities in [[Benghazi|Benghazi, Libya]] by members of the [[Islamic militant]] group [[Ansar al-Sharia (Libya)|Ansar al-Sharia]]. At 9:40 p.m., September 11, members of Ansar al-Sharia attacked the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi resulting in the deaths of [[U.S. Ambassador]] to Libya [[J. Christopher Stevens]] and [[United States Foreign Service|U.S. Foreign Service]] Information Management Officer [[Sean Smith (diplomat)|Sean Smith]].{{cite news|url=http://www.intelligence.senate.gov/benghazi2014/benghazi.pdf |date=January 15, 2014 |title=U.S. Senate Select Committee Review of the Terrorist Attacks on U.S. Diplomatic Facilities in Benghazi, Libya, September 11–12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116130132/http://www.intelligence.senate.gov/benghazi2014/benghazi.pdf |archivedate=January 16, 2014 |df= }}{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/timeline-how-the-benghazi-attack-played-out/2014/06/17/a5c34e90-f62c-11e3-a3a5-42be35962a52_story.html|title=Timeline: Here's how the Benghazi attacks played out|website=Washington Post|access-date=September 28, 2016}} Stevens was the first U.S. ambassador killed in the line of duty since 1979.{{cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2012/09/12/christopher-stevens-first-american-ambassador-slain-duty-since/eEc8mnxx6phcWSeJ1uMnsM/story.html|title=Christopher Stevens first American ambassador to be slain on duty since 1979|date=September 13, 2013|work=The Boston Globe}} At around 4:00 a.m. on September 12, the group launched a mortar attack against a [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] annex approximately {{convert|1|mi|km|adj=on|spell=in}} away, killing CIA contractors [[Tyrone S. Woods]] and [[Glen Doherty]]{{cite news| url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2012/11/02/US-officials-CIA-ran-Benghazi-consulate/UPI-44771351839600/ |title=US officials: CIA ran Benghazi consulate |date=November 2, 2012 |agency=United Press International}}{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2014/01/27/clinton-says-benghazi-is-her-biggest-regret/ |title=Clinton says Benghazi is her biggest regret |author=Aaron Blake | date=January 27, 2014 | work=The Washington Post}} and wounding ten others. At the behest of the CIA, top U.S. officials initially described the attacks as the results of a spontaneous protest triggered by the recently released anti-Muslim video, ''[[Innocence of Muslims]]''.{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2012/11/16/flashback-what-susan-rice-said-about-benghazi/|title=Flashback: What Susan Rice Said About Benghazi|last=Epstein|first=Reid J.|date=November 16, 2014|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=November 11, 2014}}
{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/16/world/africa/election-year-stakes-overshadow-nuances-of-benghazi-investigation.html|title=Election-Year Stakes Overshadow Nuances of Libya Investigation|last=Kirkpatrick|first=David|date=October 15, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=November 7, 2015}} Subsequent investigations showed that the attack was premeditated – although rioters and looters not originally part of the group may have joined in after the attacks began.{{cite news|url=http://thecable.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2012/10/09/state_department_no_video_protest_at_the_benghazi_consulate|title=State Department: No Protest at the Benghazi consulate|last=Rogin|first=Josh|date=October 9, 2012|newspaper=The Cable|accessdate=November 11, 2014}}{{subscription required}}
{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/12/04/cia-witnesses-offer-more-evidence-benghazi-attack-planned/|title=CIA witnesses offer more evidence Benghazi attack planned|last=Herridge|first=Cathrine|date=December 4, 2013|publisher=Fox News Channel|accessdate=November 11, 2014}}
{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/09/27/world/africa/libya-consulate-attack/|title=Panetta: Terrorists 'clearly' planned Benghazi attack|last=Starr|first=Barbara|date=September 27, 2012|publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 7, 2015}}
{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/18/world/middleeast/apprehension-of-ahmed-abu-khattala-may-begin-to-answer-questions-on-assault.html?hp&_r=2|title=Brazen Figure May Hold Key to Mysteries|date=June 17, 2014|work=The New York Times|author=David D. Kirkpatrick|accessdate=June 21, 2014}}
{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/19/world/africa/suspect-in-benghazi-attack-scoffs-at-us.html?pagewanted=all|title=Suspect in Libya Attack, in Plain Sight, Scoffs at U.S.|date=October 18, 2012|work=The New York Times|author=David D. Kirkpatrick|accessdate=June 21, 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-libya-consulate-attack-idUSBRE89H19P20121018|title=Exclusive:Libyan Islamist says he was at U.S. consulate during attack|date=October 18, 2012|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=October 2, 2016}} The ''[[National Review]]'' later labeled the attack '''Battle of Benghazi''',{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/332961/lessons-battle-benghazi-clifford-d-may#|title=Lessons of the Battle of Benghazi|date=November 8, 2012|newspaper=National Review Online|quote=Now that the election is behind us, perhaps we can put politics aside and acknowledge a hard fact: On September 11, 2012, America was defeated by al-Qaeda in the Battle of Benghazi.|author=May, Clifford D.|accessdate=November 11, 2012}}
{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2012/09/libya-fast-team/|title=What Happened in Benghazi Was a Battle|date=November 12, 2012|newspaper=Wired|quote=Which means the next battle of Benghazi could be even more intense than the last.|author=Ackerman, Spencer|accessdate=November 11, 2012}}
{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2012/10/30/to-live-and-die-in-benghazi-libya-without-leadership-from-america/|title=To live and die in Benghazi, Libya without leadership from America|date=October 30, 2012|publisher=Fox News Channel|quote=This battle of Benghazi was a protracted fight—covering at least six to eight hours (depending on when you start the clock).|author=Shaffer, Tony|accessdate=November 11, 2012}}
{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IgvnAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT226|title=13 Hours: The Inside Account of What Really Happened In Benghazi|date=September 9, 2014|publisher=[[Grand Central Publishing]]|isbn=978-1-4555-8229-7|page=226|quote=When the Libyan C-130 took flight bearing the last operators and the four bodies, the Battle of Benghazi ended as a combat engagement between Americans and their enemies.|author=Mitchell Zuckoff}}
{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/332961/lessons-battle-benghazi-clifford-d-may|title=Lessons of the Battle of Benghazi|last=May|first=Clifford D.|date=November 8, 2012|publisher=National Review Institute|quote=On September 11, 2012, America was defeated by al-Qaeda in the Battle of Benghazi.|website=[[National Review]]|accessdate=March 31, 2015}} a name that has since been used by several media outlets to refer to the attacks. There is no definitive evidence that al-Qaeda or any other international terrorist organization participated in the Benghazi attack.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/12/28/benghazi-new-york-times/4232109/|title=N.Y. Times probe finds no al-Qaeda link to Benghazi raid|date=December 28, 2013|publisher=USATODAY}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/12/28/us/libya-benghazi-nyt-report/|title=New York Times report casts doubt on al Qaeda involvement in Benghazi|date=December 30, 2013|publisher=cnn.com}}{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/02/26/282921143/in-benghazi-u-s-intelligence-wasnt-focused-on-homegrown-militants|title=In Benghazi, US Intelligence Wasn't Focused On 'Homegrown Militants'|date=February 26, 2014|publisher=npr.com}}
{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=282921143|title=Transcript: In Benghazi, US Intelligence Wasn't Focused On 'Homegrown Militants'|date=February 26, 2014|publisher=npr.com}} The United States immediately increased security worldwide at diplomatic and military facilities and began investigating the Benghazi attack.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505263_162-57550337/cia-talking-points-for-susan-rice-called-benghazi-attack-spontaneously-inspired-by-protests/|title=CIA talking points for Susan Rice called Benghazi attack 'spontaneously inspired' by protests|date=November 15, 2012|publisher=CBS News}} Many Libyans condemned the attacks. They staged public demonstrations condemning Ansar al-Sharia, which had been formed during the [[2011 Libyan Civil War|2011 Libyan civil war]] in opposition to leader Colonel [[Muammar Gaddafi]]. Despite persistent accusations against President Obama, Hillary Clinton, and [[Susan Rice]], [[Investigation into the 2012 Benghazi attack|ten investigations]] — six by Republican-controlled congressional committees — did not find that they or any other high-ranking Obama administration officials had acted improperly. Four career [[United States Department of State|State Department]] officials were criticized for denying requests for additional security at the facility prior to the attack. [[Eric J. Boswell]], the Assistant Secretary of State for Diplomatic Security, resigned under pressure, while three others were suspended.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/ap-three-state-dept-officials-to-resign-after-scathing-benghazi-report/2012/12/19/ad4ca7e8-49fc-11e2-820e-17eefac2f939_story.html|title=Four State Dept. officials disciplined after Benghazi probe|first1=Anne|last1=Gearan|first2=Greg|last2=Miller|date=December 19, 2012|publisher=|accessdate=April 1, 2018|via=www.washingtonpost.com}} In her role as [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]], [[Hillary Clinton]] subsequently took responsibility for the security lapses.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/transcript-hillary-clinton-takes-responsibility-benghazi-attack-article-1.1246025|title=Transcript of Hillary Clinton's testimony on Benghazi attack |newspaper=New York Daily News}} On August 6, 2013, it was reported that the U.S. had filed criminal charges against several individuals alleged to have been involved in the attacks, including militia leader [[Ahmed Abu Khattala]].{{cite news|last=Perez |first=Evan |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/08/06/politics/benghazi-charges/index.html |title=First criminal charges filed in Benghazi attack probe |publisher=CNN |date=August 7, 2013 |accessdate=September 5, 2013}} Khattala has been described by Libyan and U.S. officials as the Benghazi leader of Ansar al-Sharia. The U.S. Department of State designated Ansar al-Sharia as a [[List of designated terrorist groups|terrorist organization]] in January 2014.{{cite web |title= Terrorist Designations of Three Ansar al-Shari'a Organizations and Leaders|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2014/01/219519.htm|publisher=U.S. Department of State|date=January 10, 2014 |accessdate=June 19, 2014}}{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/31/politics/benghazi-investigation-suspect/index.html |title= Lawmaker: If CNN can interview suspect in Benghazi attack, why can't FBI? | date=August 7, 2013 | publisher=CNN |author1=John King |author2=Chelsea J. Carter |accessdate=May 8, 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2014/04/03/new-york-times-stands-by-benghazi-story/ |author=Erik Wemple|date=April 3, 2014|title=New York Times stands by Benghazi story|work=The Washington Post |accessdate=May 8, 2014}} Khattala was captured in Libya by U.S. Army [[Special Operations Forces]], who were acting in coordination with the [[FBI]], in June 2014.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/us-captured-benghazi-suspect-in-secret-raid/2014/06/17/7ef8746e-f5cf-11e3-a3a5-42be35962a52_story.html?Post+generic=%3Ftid%3Dsm_twitter_washingtonpost|title=U.S. captures Benghazi suspect in secret raid|work=The Washington Post}} Another suspect, Mustafa al-Imam, was captured in October 2017.{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/africaTech/idAFKBN1D01G8-OZATP|title=Man seized over Benghazi attack is Syrian linked to suspected ringleader -Libyan officials|publisher=Reuters}} ==Background== ===American presence in Libya and Benghazi=== Within months of the start of the Libyan revolution in February 2011, the CIA began building a covert presence in Benghazi.Schmitt, Eric; Cooper, Helene; Schmidt, Michael S. [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/24/world/africa/attack-in-libya-was-major-blow-to-cia-efforts.html?_r=1& "Deadly Attack in Libya Was Major Blow to CIA Efforts"] ''The New York Times'', September 23, 2012. During the war, elite counterterrorist operators from U.S. [[Delta Force]] were deployed to Libya as analysts, instructing the rebels on specifics about weapons and tactics.{{cite book|last=Murphy|first=Jack and Brandon Webb|title=Benghazi: The Definitive report|year=2013|publisher=HarperCollins Inc.|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-0-06-227691-9|pages=25–58}}{{rp|16}} Ambassador [[J. Christopher Stevens]] was named the first liaison with the Libyan opposition in March 2011.Cox, Carmen. [http://abcnewsradioonline.com/world-news/us-names-chris-stevens-liaison-to-libyan-opposition.html "U.S. Names Chris Stevens Liaison to Libyan Opposition"] ABC News, March 14, 2011. After the end of the war, both the [[CIA]] and the U.S. State Department were tasked with continuing to identify and collect arms that had flooded the country during the war, particularly [[shoulder-fired missile]]s taken from the arsenal of the Gaddafi regime,Ross, Brian; Cole, Matthew. [http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/nightmare-libya-20000-surface-air-missiles-missing/story?id=14610199 "Nightmare in Libya: Thousands of Surface-to-Air Missiles Unaccounted For"] ABC News, September 27, 2011.Coughlin, Con. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/columnists/concoughlin/8843708/Will-a-Middle-East-awash-with-weapons-be-Gaddafis-final-legacy.html "Will a Middle East awash with weapons be Gaddafi's final legacy?"] ''The Telegraph'', October 23, 2011. as well as securing Libyan chemical weapons stockpiles, and helping to train Libya's new intelligence service. Eastern Libya and Benghazi were key intelligence-gathering hubs for intelligence operatives. Before the attack, the CIA was monitoring [[Ansar al-Sharia (Libya)|Ansar al-Sharia]] and suspected members of [[Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]], as well as attempting to define the leadership and loyalty of the various militias present and their interaction with the [[Salafi movement|Salafi]] elements of Libyan society. By the time of the attack, dozens of CIA operatives were on the ground in Benghazi.Griffin, Drew; Johnston, Kathleen. [http://thelead.blogs.cnn.com/2013/08/01/exclusive-dozens-of-cia-operatives-on-the-ground-during-benghazi-attack/ "Exclusive: Dozens of CIA operatives on the ground during Benghazi attack"] CNN, August 1, 2013. Hicks, testified that Ambassador Stevens was in Benghazi in 2012 because "Secretary [of State Hillary] Clinton wanted the post made permanent", and it was understood that the secretary hoped to make
