The hearing testimony revealed that "Hicks argued that Rice's comments so insulted the Libyan president—since they contradicted his Sept. 16 claims that the attack was premeditated—that it slowed the FBI's investigation. 'President Magariaf was insulted in front of his own people, in front of the world. His credibility was reduced,' Hicks said, adding that the president was apparently 'still steamed' two weeks later."{{cite news |title=Whistle-blower: Botched talking points hurt FBI probe of Benghazi attack | url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/05/08/whistle-blowers-testify-on-benghazi-attacks/ | publisher=Fox News Channel | date=May 8, 2013 |accessdate=May 9, 2013}}
{{cite news |title=The latest on Benghazi hearing |url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2013/05/08/the-latest-on-benghazi-hearing/comment-page-11/ |publisher=CNN |date=May 8, 2013 |accessdate=June 3, 2013}} To assist the Libyan government in disbanding extremist groups, the Obama administration allocated $8 million to begin building an elite Libyan commando force over the next year.{{cite news|title=U.S. to Help Create an Elite Libyan Force to Combat Islamic Extremists|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/16/world/africa/us-to-help-create-libyan-commando-force.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 15, 2012 |first=Eric |last=Schmitt}} In the Presidential debate of October 16, 2012, between President Obama and [[Mitt Romney]], Romney claimed that "it took the president 14 days before he called the attack in Benghazi an act of terror." President Obama responded, "The day after the attack, governor, I stood in the Rose Garden and I told the American people and the world that we are going to find out exactly what happened," Obama said. "That this was an act of terror, and I also said that we're going to hunt down those who committed this crime."{{cite news |title=CNN Fact Check: A day after Libya attack, Obama described it as 'acts of terror' |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/17/politics/fact-check-terror |publisher=CNN |date=October 17, 2012 |accessdate=July 3, 2013}} When Romney challenged Obama, asking "You said in the Rose Garden the day after the attack, it was an act of terror. On October 19, 2012, House Oversight Committee Chairman [[Darrell Issa]] (R-CA) came under fire from intelligence officials in the Obama administration when he posted, on a public website, 166 pages of sensitive but unclassified State Department communications related to Libya. According to officials, the release of the unredacted documents compromised the identities of several Libyans working with the U.S. government and placed their lives in danger.[http://thecable.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2012/10/19/issa_s_benghazi_document_dump_exposes_several_libyans_working_with_the_us Josh Rogin, "Issa's Benghazi document dump exposes several Libyans working with the U.S."] ''Foreign Policy'', October 19, 2012. On [[CBS|CBS's]] ''[[Face the Nation]]'' on October 28, Senator John McCain (R-AZ) stated that "this is either a massive cover-up or incompetence" and suggested that it was a scandal worse than [[Watergate scandal|Watergate]]. Consequently, her testimony was postponed.{{Cite news |title=Hillary Clinton Benghazi Testimony Postponed After Secretary Of State Sustains Concussion |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/15/hillary-clinton-benghazi-testimony_n_2308153.html |publisher=The Huffington Post |date=December 15, 2012}} The incident prompted Republican Rep. But you know, to be clear, it is, from my perspective, less important today looking backwards as to why these militants decided they did it than to find them and bring them to justice, and then maybe we'll figure out what was going on in the meantime.{{Cite news |title=In Context: Hillary Clinton's 'What difference does it make' comment |url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2013/may/08/context-hillary-clintons-what-difference-does-it-m/ |work=Tampa Bay Times |date=May 7, 2013 |accessdate=July 16, 2015}}

GOP legislators also took issue with delays in the investigation, which CNN attributed to "bureaucratic infighting" between the FBI, [[United States Department of Justice|Justice]], and [[United States Department of State|State]]. On September 26, Senator [[Johnny Isakson]] (R-Georgia) said he "cannot believe that the FBI is not on the ground yet". Testimony from top U.S. commanders after the attack revealed that the military was unprepared for conflict across Africa and the Middle East. No attack aircraft had been placed on high alert on September 11, the anniversary of the [[September 11 attacks]] in 2001, and the closest fighter planes to trouble spots in North Africa were based in Aviano, Italy. The fighter planes based in Aviano were unarmed and no aerial refueling planes were within a 10-hour flight to the base. In addition, no [[AC-130]] gunships were within a 10-hour flight of Libya, and their crews did not reach a staging base in Italy until 19 hours after the attack began.{{cite news |title=The Benghazi Republican Presidents and then President Obama until stepping down in July 2011, has said that some critics of the government's response have a "cartoonish" view of military capabilities. He stated that he would have responded with equal caution given the risks and the lack of intelligence on the ground, and that American forces require planning and preparation, which the circumstances did not allow for.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-3460_162-57584087/gates-some-benghazi-critics-have-cartoonish-view-of-military-capability/ |title=Gates: Some Benghazi critics have "cartoonish" view of military capability. |publisher=CBS News |accessdate=May 14, 2013}} President Obama called the criticism a "sideshow"{{cite news |title=President Obama Dismisses Benghazi Criticism as 'Sideshow' |author=Saenz, Arlette |url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2013/05/president-obama-dismisses-benghazi-criticism-as-sideshow/ |publisher=ABC News |date=May 13, 2013 |accessdate=May 19, 2013}}
{{cite news |title=Obama calls Benghazi controversy a 'sideshow' |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/05/13/obama-calls-benghazi-controversy-sideshow/ |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=May 13, 2013 |accessdate=May 19, 2013}} and later accused Congress of "taking its eye off the ball" on the subject of the economy and focusing on "phony scandals". White House Spokesman Jay Carney later specified that the criticism of the administration's handling of the Benghazi attacks was one of those "phony scandals".{{cite news|last=Schwartz |first=Ian |url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2013/07/31/carney_identifies_which_scandals_obama_thinks_are_phony_benghazi_and_irs.html |title=Carney Identifies Which Scandals Obama Thinks Are Phony: Benghazi And IRS |publisher=RealClearPolitics |date=July 31, 2013 |accessdate=September 5, 2013}} On December 10, 2014, upon publication of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence report on Benghazi,{{cite web|title=Investigative Report on the Terrorist Attacks on U.S. Facilities in Benghazi, Libya, September 11–12, 2012|url=http://intelligence.house.gov/sites/intelligence.house.gov/files/documents/Benghazi%20Report.pdf|publisher=United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|accessdate=July 17, 2015}} Committee Chairman [[Mike Rogers (Michigan politician)|Mike Rogers]] wrote in an op-ed piece, "The Obama administration's White House and State Department actions before, during, and after the Benghazi terrorist attack on September 11, 2012, ranged from incompetence to deplorable political manipulation in the midst of an election season."{{cite news|last=Rogers |first=Mike |url=http://thehill.com/opinion/op-ed/226635-the-house-intelligence-committees-report-on-benghazi |title=The House Intelligence Committee's report on Benghazi (op-ed) |newspaper=The Hill |date=December 10, 2014 |accessdate=July 17, 2015}} However, immediately upon release of the Committee's report on November 21, 2014, the ''Associated Press'' reported that the Committee did not conclude that any "government official acted in bad faith or intentionally misled the American people." For actions in Benghazi during the attack, a Marine was awarded the [[Navy Cross]], and a Soldier was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Cross (United States)|Distinguished Service Cross]]; their names have been held in secret.{{cite news |last=Vanden Brook |first=Tom |title=Navy SEALs secret medals reveal heroism during past 15 years |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2016/05/15/navy-seals-secret-medals-reveal-heroism-during-past-15-years/84242220/ |work=USA Today |location= |date=May 16, 2016 |access-date=April 23, 2018 }}
{{cite news |first=Rowan |last=Scarborough |title=Delta Force Marine awarded Navy Cross for fight at CIA annex in Benghazi |url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/nov/16/delta-force-marine-awarded-navy-cross-fight-cia-an/ |work=Washington Times |date=November 16, 2013 |access-date=April 23, 2018 }}
{{cite news |author= |title=2 US commandos involved in Benghazi rescue to be privately honored for bravery |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/11/01/two-us-commandos-involved-in-benghazi-rescue-to-be-privately-honored-for.html |work=Fox News |date=November 1, 2013 |access-date=April 23, 2018 }} ===U.S. media response=== Multiple conservative media outlets, most notably Fox News, promulgated an elaborate narrative of a scandal and cover-up by officials of the Obama administration, including, among other things, accusations that officials issued a "stand-down order" to preclude a military rescue operation; that officials knowingly lied by repeatedly asserting the attack was spontaneously triggered by the [[Innocence of Muslims]] video rather than a pre-planned terrorist attack; that a secret CIA gun-running operation to Syrian rebels was being conducted out of Libya; that President Obama and Hillary Clinton were absent and negligent on the night of the attack; that Hillary Clinton had personally declined multiple requests for more security at the compound; that a live video feed of the attack was viewed at the White House or State Department; that Ambassador Stevens had been captured by terrorists and dragged through the streets; and that witnesses had been prevented from testifying. These accusations were widely shared across various blogs and social media platforms. Ultimately, none of the accusations of scandal and cover-up were confirmed by any of the [[Investigation into the 2012 Benghazi attack|ten Benghazi investigations]], including six investigations conducted by Republican-controlled congressional committees. The [[Center for Media and Public Affairs]] at George Mason University described the conclusions of an unpublished study on November 2, 2012. Based on a textual analysis that tallied the occurrence of certain words and phrases in news reports during the days immediately following the attack, the study concluded that leading newspapers in the U.S. framed the attack in terms of a spontaneous protest over the anti-Islamic film ''[[Innocence of Muslims]]'' as framed by the Obama administration's version, four times as often as a planned terrorist attack, which was the Republican version.{{cite news |title=Study: Media accepted Obama version of Benghazi attack |author=Dinan, Stephen |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/blog/inside-politics/2012/nov/2/study-media-accepted-obama-version-benghazi-attack/ |newspaper=The Washington Times |date=November 2, 2012 |accessdate=June 3, 2013}} However, the 2014 final report by the Republican-controlled [[House Intelligence Committee]] found that during the days immediately following the attack there was confusion among intelligence analysts as to the origin of the attack, leading to an initial assessment that it was the spontaneous outcome from a protest. Obama administration officials, most notably [[Susan Rice]], were provided this early assessment and repeated it to media outlets, only to be later contradicted as further intelligence assessments were made.{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2013/05/benghazi-memo-drafts/315398/|title=The Benghazi Memo Drafts, as They Evolved|first=Philip|last=Bump|publisher=|accessdate=April 1, 2018}} None of the ten investigations into Benghazi found that any senior Obama administration officials had acted improperly. On September 13, [[Rachel Maddow]], during her show on [[MSNBC]], stated:
An organized attack. Anybody who tells you that what happened to our ambassador and our consulate in Libya was as a result of a protest over an offensive movie, you should ask them why they think that. That's the first version of events we heard. That does not seem to explain what happened that night or by the facts or the more facts we get.{{Cite news|title=The Rachel Maddow Show|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/49033879/ns/msnbc-rachel_maddow_show/t/rachel-maddow-show-thursday-september-th/#.UaqDx-tAtyB|publisher=MSNBC|date=September 13, 2012}}
On June 2014, Maddow criticized the right-wing media for reporting an arrest as bad news, said that Americas are poorly served by the media, and that "the take on Fox News is that's not actually news" and now "they have to make it bad news, they have to make into maybe a scandal itself."{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow-show/watch/media-fails-americans-on-iraq-benghazi-283294275959|title=Americans poorly served by media on Iraq, Benghazi|accessdate=June 25, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Maddow: U.S. Got the Suspect and 'Benghazi Central' Fox News Doesn't Care?|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/maddow-u-s-got-the-suspect-and-%E2%80%98benghazi-central%E2%80%99-fox-news-doesn%E2%80%99t-care|accessdate=June 25, 2014}} On the edition of October 24 of Fox News' ''Special Report with Bret Baier'', syndicated columnist [[Charles Krauthammer]] claimed that a State Department e-mail, which passed along a report from Embassy Tripoli that Ansar al-Sharia had claimed responsibility for the attack on Facebook and Twitter,{{cite news|author=Hosenball, Mark|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/24/us-usa-benghazi-emails-idUSBRE89N02C20121024|title=White House told of militant claim two hours after Libya attack: emails|agency=Reuters|date=October 23, 2012|accessdate=June 21, 2013}}{{cite news|author=Schmitt, Eric|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/25/world/africa/us-e-mails-reveal-early-views-of-libya-attack.html|title=E-Mails Offer Glimpse at What U.S. Knew in First Hours After Attack in Libya|work=The New York Times|date=October 23, 2012|accessdate=June 21, 2013}} proved that the White House knew of terrorist connections to the attack almost immediately. Krauthammer stated, "This is really a journalistic scandal. I mean, the fact there was not a word about any of this in the [New York] Times or the [Washington] Post today."{{Cite news|title= Krauthammer: Lack of Benghazi media coverage 'a journalistic scandal'|url=http://dailycaller.com/2012/10/25/krauthammer-lack-of-benghazi-media-coverage-a-journalistic-scandal/ |publisher=The Daily Caller|date=October 25, 2012}} However, the day after the Benghazi attack, Ansar al-Sharia issued a statement saying that the attack was in part "a spontaneous popular uprising in response to what happened by the West," which was an apparent reference to the [[Innocence of Muslims]] video. Conservative pundit [[Jonah Goldberg]] of the ''[[National Review]]'' stated that on NBC's ''[[Meet the Press]]'', host [[David Gregory (journalist)|David Gregory]] changed the subject when a guest raised the subject of the Benghazi attack, saying, "Let's get to Libya a little bit later", but never returned to the subject.{{Cite news|title= Benghazi: No 'October Surprise'|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/332103/benghazi-no-october-surprise-jonah-goldberg# |work= National Review|date=October 31, 2012}}{{cite news|title=October 28: John Kasich, Scott Walker, John Hickenlooper, E.J. Dionne, Rachel Maddow, Carly Fiorina, David Brooks|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/49557307/ns/meet_the_press-transcripts/t/october-john-kasich-scott-walker-john-hickenlooper-ej-dionne-rachel-maddow-carly-fiorina-david-brooks-chuck-todd|publisher=MSNBC|date=October 28, 2012|accessdate=December 18, 2012}} On November 26, 2012, journalist [[Thomas E. Ricks (journalist)|Tom Ricks]] went on Fox News' ''[[Happening Now]]'' with [[Jon Scott]] to discuss the attack. While being interviewed on Fox News by Jon Scott, Ricks accused Fox News of being "extremely political" in its coverage of the attack and said that "Fox was operating as a wing of the [[United States Republican Party|Republican Party]]." Ricks accused the network of covering the story more than it needed to be. The interview was cut short and Ricks and the interview was not mentioned or covered by Fox News again. Fox News was subsequently criticized for cutting the interview short.{{cite news|author=Weinger, Mackenzie |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/media/2012/11/tom-ricks-to-fox-news-the-network-operates-as-a-wing-150296.html |title=Tom Ricks to Fox News: The network operates 'as a wing of the Republican Party' |publisher=Politico |date=November 26, 2012 |accessdate=December 11, 2012}}{{cite news|author=Wemple, Erik |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/post/ricks-fox-doesnt-care-about-story-behind-benghazi-story/2012/11/27/b4f4ee0e-38ab-11e2-b01f-5f55b193f58f_blog.html |title=Ricks: Fox doesn't care about story behind Benghazi story |work=The Washington Post |date=November 27, 2012 |accessdate=December 11, 2012}} In an interview with the Associated Press, Fox News' White House correspondent [[Ed Henry]] suggested that he thought Benghazi was being covered too much by the network. Henry said, "We've had the proper emphasis, but I would not be so deluded to say that some of our shows, some of our commentators, have covered it more than it needed to be covered."{{cite news|author=Wemple, Erik |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2012/12/06/does-fox-newss-ed-henry-agree-with-tom-ricks/ |title=Does Fox News's Ed Henry agree with Tom Ricks? |work=The Washington Post |date=December 6, 2012 |accessdate=December 11, 2012}}{{cite news|author=Bauder, David |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/06/ed-henry-fox-news-benghazi_n_2249659.html |title=Ed Henry: Some Fox News Shows Covered Benghazi 'More Than It Needed To Be' |publisher=The Huffington Post |date=December 6, 2012 |accessdate=December 11, 2012}} ==Investigations== {{Main|Investigation into the 2012 Benghazi attack |Timeline of the investigation into the 2012 Benghazi attack}} There were ten investigations into the Benghazi matter: one by the FBI; one by an independent board commissioned by the State Department; two by Democrat-controlled Senate Committees; and six by Republican-controlled House Committees. After the first five Republican investigations found no evidence of wrongdoing by senior Obama administration officials, Republicans in 2014 opened a sixth investigation, the [[United States House Select Committee on Benghazi|House Select Committee on Benghazi]], chaired by [[Trey Gowdy]]. This investigation also failed to find any evidence of wrongdoing by senior Obama administration officials. A possible political motive for the investigation was revealed on September 29, 2015, when Republican House majority leader [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]], then vying to become Speaker of the House, told [[Sean Hannity]] on Fox News that the investigation was part of a "strategy to fight and win,' adding "Everybody thought Hillary Clinton was unbeatable, right? But we put together a Benghazi special committee, a select committee. What are her numbers today? Her numbers are dropping."{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2015/09/30/politics/kevin-mccarthy-benghazi-committee-speaker/index.html|title=House Republicans repudiate Kevin McCarthy comments - CNNPolitics|first=Manu Raju, Deirdre Walsh and Tal Kopan,|last=CNN|publisher=|accessdate=April 2, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://video.foxnews.com/v/4519442873001/?#sp=show-clips|title=Rep. Kevin McCarthy how he would differ from John Boehner|date=September 29, 2015|website=Fox News|accessdate=April 2, 2018}} Shortly after the Benghazi attack, Secretary of State Clinton commissioned an independent Accountability Review Board to investigate, chaired by retired ambassador [[Thomas R. Pickering]] with vice-chair retired Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff [[Michael Mullen]]. The Board released their final report on December 19, 2012.https://www.hsdl.org/?abstract&did=727502 It made 29 recommendations to the State Department on how to improve its operations, which Clinton pledged to implement.https://2009-2017.state.gov/documents/organization/203244.pdf As part of this investigation, four career State Department officials were criticized for denying requests for additional security at the facility prior to the attack. By the end of 2012, [[Eric J. Boswell]], the Assistant Secretary of State for Diplomatic Security, resigned under pressure, while three others were suspended.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/ap-three-state-dept-officials-to-resign-after-scathing-benghazi-report/2012/12/19/ad4ca7e8-49fc-11e2-820e-17eefac2f939_story.html|title=Four State Dept. officials disciplined after Benghazi probe|first1=Anne|last1=Gearan|first2=Greg|last2=Miller|date=December 19, 2012|publisher=|accessdate=April 2, 2018|via=www.washingtonpost.com}} None of the other Benghazi investigations identified wrongdoing by any individuals. The [[United States House Select Committee on Benghazi|House Select Committee on Benghazi]]'s final report was released on June 28, 2016 and the committee closed down five months later.{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/house-benghazi-committee-files-final-report-shuts-down-n695181|title=House Benghazi committee files final report and shuts down|publisher=|accessdate=April 2, 2018}} No further public investigations have been conducted since. The findings of the two-year investigation by the Republican-controlled [[House Intelligence Committee]], the fifth of six Republican investigations, was summarized by the ''Associated Press'' on November 21, 2014:{{cite web|url=https://apnews.com/ecc3a300383445d5a90dd6ca764c9e15|title=House intel panel debunks many Benghazi theories|publisher=|accessdate=April 2, 2018}} {{quote|A two-year investigation by the Republican-controlled House Intelligence Committee has found that the CIA and the military acted properly in responding to the 2012 attack on a U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, and asserted no wrongdoing by Obama administration appointees. Debunking a series of persistent allegations hinting at dark conspiracies, the investigation of the politically charged incident determined that there was no intelligence failure, no delay in sending a CIA rescue team, no missed opportunity for a military rescue, and no evidence the CIA was covertly shipping arms from Libya to Syria. In the immediate aftermath of the attack, intelligence about who carried it out and why was contradictory, the report found. That led Susan Rice, then U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, to inaccurately assert that the attack had evolved from a protest, when in fact there had been no protest. But it was intelligence analysts, not political appointees, who made the wrong call, the committee found. The report did not conclude that Rice or any other government official acted in bad faith or intentionally misled the American people. ... In the aftermath of the attacks, Republicans criticized the Obama administration and its then-secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is expected to run for president in 2016. People in and out of government have alleged that a CIA response team was ordered to "stand down" after the State Department compound came under attack, that a military rescue was nixed, that officials intentionally downplayed the role of al-Qaida figures in the attack, and that Stevens and the CIA were involved in a secret operation to spirit weapons out of Libya and into the hands of Syrian rebels. None of that is true, according to the House Intelligence Committee report. The report did find, however, that the State Department facility where Stevens and Smith were killed was not well-protected, and that State Department security agents knew they could not defend it from a well-armed attack. Previous reports have found that requests for security improvements were not acted upon in Washington.}} ==FOIA requests== [[File:Montage of 7 FOIA photographs from Department of State.jpg|thumb|700px|Montage of seven photographs released under a FOIA request from Judicial Watch to the Department of State]] [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] requests have been made since the attack. The conservative foundation [[Judicial Watch]] filed a FOIA request to the Department of State on December 19, 2012. An acknowledgement of the request was received by Judicial Watch on January 4, 2013. When the State Department failed to respond to the request by February 4, 2013, Judicial Watch filed a lawsuit, which resulted in seven photographs being delivered on June 6, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.judicialwatch.org/press-room/press-releases/judicial-watch-obtains-first-photos-from-state-department-depicting-aftermath-of-benghazi-attack/|title=Judicial Watch Obtains First Photos from State Department Depicting Aftermath of Benghazi Attack|publisher=Judicial Watch|date=June 21, 2013|accessdate=August 23, 2012}} Three of the photographs show Arabic-language spray paint graffiti. According to preliminary translations provided to the U.K. MailOnline by the Investigative Project on Terrorism, the graffiti likely reads "Thrones of HamzaIn"; "Allah-u Akbar" ("God is Great"); and "Unity of ranks".{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2345440/Allah-u-Akbar-State-Department-unclassifies-releases-official-photos-aftermath-2012-Benghazi-attack-including-jihadi-graffiti-left-behind.html|title='Allah-u-Akbar': State Department unclassifies first official photos from aftermath of Benghazi attack, including jihadi graffiti left behind |work=[[Daily Mail]] |date=June 20, 2013 |location=London|first=David|last=Martosko |accessdate=August 23, 2012}} On May 30, 2013 it was reported that the [[Republican National Committee]] filed a FOIA for "any and all emails or other documents containing the terms 'Libya' and/or 'Benghazi' dated between September 11, 2012 and November 7, 2012 directed from or to U.S. Department of State employees originating from, or addressed to, persons whose email addresses end in either 'barackobama.com' or 'dnc.org'{{-"}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.humanevents.com/2013/05/30/rnc-files-foia-request-for-benghazi-emails-between-state-dept-and-obama-2012-campaign/|title=RNC Files FOIA Request for Benghazi Emails Between State Dept. and Obama 2012 Campaign|publisher=Human Events|date=May 30, 2013|accessdate=August 23, 2012}} On April 18, 2014, the conservative group [[Judicial Watch]] released more than 100 pages of documents obtained through a FOIA lawsuit.{{cite web|url=http://www.judicialwatch.org/press-room/press-releases/judicial-watch-benghazi-documents-point-white-house-misleading-talking-points/|title=Judicial Watch: Benghazi Documents Point to White House on Misleading Talking Points|publisher=Judicial Watch|date=April 18, 2014|accessdate=April 29, 2014}} One [https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3a/Rhodes_email.jpg email], dated September 14, 2012, with a subject line "RE PREP CALL with Susan: Saturday at 4:00 pm ET", was from deputy national security advisor for strategic communications Rhodes stated:{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2014/04/30/benghazi-emails-obama-white-house-put-politics-ahead-truth/|title=Benghazi emails: Proof Obama White House put politics ahead of truth|author=Jay Sekulow|publisher=Fox News Channel}} "Goals: ... To underscore that these protests are rooted in an Internet video, and not a broader failure of policy..."[http://www.judicialwatch.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/1919_production-4-17-14.pdf#page=14 "Documents obtained through FOIA"] by Judicial Watch. Retrieved May 4, 2014. According to another e-mail obtained by Judicial Watch, when asked about whether the attack was linked to the Mohammad video, State Department spokesperson [[Victoria Nuland]] said she "could not confirm a connect as we simply don't know—and we won't know until there is an investigation".{{cite web|url=http://www.judicialwatch.org/document-archive/knopf-email-toria-nuland-2/|title=Knopf Email on Toria Nuland Information Page 2 |publisher=Judicial Watch}} According to ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', the e-mail was written to prepare U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. [[Susan Rice]] for her appearances on Sunday news shows two days later, and it "sets out the Administration's view of the cause of the Benghazi attacks".{{cite news |title=The missing Benghazi email |url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303678404579533671320855450 |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=April 30, 2014 |accessdate=May 28, 2014}} [[John Dickerson (journalist)|John Dickerson]] of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' says the e-mail refers to the worldwide [[Reactions to Innocence of Muslims|protests to ''Innocence of Muslims'']] and not the Benghazi attack.[http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2014/04/benghazi_white_house_emails_did_the_obama_administration_engage_in_a_cover.html "Lies, Damned Lies, and Garden-Variety Self-Deception"] by [[John Dickerson (journalist)|John Dickerson]]. {{infobox music festival |music_festival_name = BAALS Music Festival | image= Baals official logo.png | image_caption |location = [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] |years_active = 2012–present |dates = Late July / Early August |founders = [[A Better Fort]]
Shane Araujo
[[Alex Smith (entrepreneur)|Alex Smith]] |genre = [[Trance music|Trance]], [[Dance music|dance]], [[Electronic dance music|EDM]], [[jam band]], [[House music|house]], [[drum and bass]], [[techno]], [[dance-punk]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] |website = [http://www.itsbaals.com/ Official Website] }} '''BAALS''' is a [[music festival]] which is primarily focused on electronic dance music, dance music and jam bands. The festival takes place in the city of [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] and has been organized since 2012. Each year the festival earmarks and donates $5,000 to a local charity, cause or nonprofit. The first edition of the festival took place in 2012 as a downtown block part called House 4 a House. In 2014 the festival expanded to Headwaters Park at which point it changed its name to the BAALS Music Festival. == History == The event began on July 13, 2012 as a downtown block party entitled House4aHouse. The host of the event was an advocacy group called [[A Better Fort]] who coincided the block party with another festival called The Three Rivers Festival. This block party raised $5,000, donated it to a local non-profit{{cite web|url= http://wane.com/2014/07/11/baals-summer-block-party-promises-local-djs-drink-specials-and-more/|title= #BAALS Summer Block Party Promises Local DJs, Drink Specials, and More|author= WANE Staff Reports|date= July 11, 2014|publisher=Wane.com|accessdate= December 9, 2014}} and garnered 2,000 attendees in its first year.{{cite web|url=http://www.journalgazette.net/article/20140711/ENT/307119997 |title=Building a Bigger House Party |first=Keiara |last=Carr |date=July 11, 2014 |publisher=Journal Gazette |accessdate=December 9, 2014 }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Around the inaugural year the city of Fort Wayne endured ridicule, including multiple skits on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'', as the city explored naming a government building the “Harry Baals Government Center” after a former city Mayor.{{cite web|url= http://lynchpincreative.co/2014/07/a-story-of-city-building-harry-baals-joke/97|title= A Story of City Building behind the Harry Baals Joke|date=July 7, 2014|publisher= Lynchpin Creative|accessdate=December 9, 2014}}{{cite web|url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/16/harry-baals-government-center-jimmy-kimmel_n_836564.html|title= Jimmy Kimmel Grills Ft. Wayne Mayor Over Snubbing Of 'Harry Baals' Center (VIDEO)|date=March 16, 2011|publisher= Huffington Post|accessdate=January 26, 2014}} In 2014, festival leaders changed the event name to BAALS{{cite web|url=http://www.journalgazette.net/article/20140607/LOCAL/306079976 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20141204114515/http://www.journalgazette.net/article/20140607/LOCAL/306079976 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 4, 2014 |title=Block Parties Embrace Former Mayor Baals |first=Dan |last=Stockman |date=June 7, 2014 |publisher=The Journal Gazette |accessdate=December 9, 2014 }} citing the reason for the name change is to take the recently publicized stereotypes and poke fun at them.{{cite web|url=http://www.dasfort.com/gears-behind-baals/ |title=The Gears Behind #Baals |publisher=Das Fort |accessdate=December 9, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205100929/http://www.dasfort.com/gears-behind-baals/ |archivedate=December 5, 2014 |df= }} That same year the festival amassed 10,000 attendees between the two-part series and moved to Headwaters Park in downtown Fort Wayne.{{cite web|url= http://www.21alive.com/news/local/BaaLs-Block-Party-Rocks-Downtown-266832081.html|title= #BaaLs Block Party Rocks Downtown|first= Eric|last= Dutkiewicz|date= July 11, 2014|publisher= 21 Alive|accessdate= December 9, 2014|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150220032752/http://www.21alive.com/news/local/BaaLs-Block-Party-Rocks-Downtown-266832081.html|archivedate= February 20, 2015|df= }} == Philanthropy == The BAALS Music Festival donates up to $5,000 each year to a selected local charity.{{cite web|url= http://wane.com/2014/07/03/a-better-fort-block-party-embraces-old-and-new/ |title= A Better Fort block Party References Old and New|author= Wane April M. Campbell|date=July 3, 2014|publisher=Wane.com|accessdate=December 9, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.news-sentinel.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20140703/ENT/140709894 |title=A Better Fort Plans a Pair of Block Parties for Downtown Fort Wayne |first=Jaclyn |last=Goldborough |date=July 29, 2014 |publisher=The News Sentinel |accessdate=December 9, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220031102/http://www.news-sentinel.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20140703%2FENT%2F140709894 |archivedate=February 20, 2015 |df= }} In its first three years under A Better Fort, the festival donated a total of $15,000 to the Mad Anthony Children’s Hope House.{{cite web|url=http://www.news-sentinel.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20141210/LIVING/141209888/1017/LIVING |title=Community Support: Room Sponsorship |author=News-Sentinel |date=December 10, 2014 |publisher=The News-Sentinel |accessdate=December 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220022137/http://www.news-sentinel.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20141210%2FLIVING%2F141209888%2F1017%2FLIVING |archivedate=February 20, 2015 |df= }} ==See also== {{Commons category|BAALS Music Festival}} *[[List of electronic music festivals]] *[[Live electronic music]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.itsbaals.com}} {{Electronic music festival}} {{coord|41|05|09|N|85|08|19|W|region:US-IN_type:event|display=title}} {{Rock festivals}} [[Category:Music festivals established in 2012]] [[Category:Electronic music festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Jam band festivals]] [[Category:Culture of Fort Wayne, Indiana]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Fort Wayne, Indiana]]

{{Multiple issues|{{refimprove|date=September 2018}}{{lead too long|date=September 2018}}}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = Chaos Constructions | image = ZX Spectrum prints at Chaos Constructions 2018.jpg | caption = | genre = [[demoscene]] | location = [[Saint Petersburg, Russia|Saint Petersburg]], {{flag|Russia}} | events = ChaosConf | homepage = {{URL|https://chaosconstructions.ru/en/}} | footnotes = }} {{demoscene}} '''Chaos Constructions''' is the oldest [[computer art]] festival originally related to [[demoscene]] subculture, the biggest in Russia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.demoparty.net/chaosconstructions2018/ |title=Chaos Constructions 2018 |publisher=demoparty.net |date= |accessdate=2018-09-16}}</ref> It has been held as a [[demoparty]] since 1995 and was called ''ENLiGHT'' until 1999. Traditionally it is held on a weekend at the end of August at [[Saint Petersburg, Russia]]. Creative competitions for computer artists and musicians, as well as programmers, are the important part of the event. The competitions (''"[[demoscene compo|compo]]s"'') are both for pre-released and real-time works. Many of the compos and exhibits are related to [[retro computing]] ([[ASCII art]], [[pixel art]], [[tracker music]], [[chiptune]] etc), but recent festivals also tend to include conferences and meetings for people from the modern [[IT industry]] who concentrate on technologies such as [[augmented reality|augmented]]/[[virtual reality]], [[blockchain]], [[robotics]] and more.
== History == The [[demoscene]] ({{lang-ru|русскоязычная демосцена}}) began to form in [[CIS countries]] in the early 1990s, when people massively began to possess [[home computer]]s such as [[ZX Spectrum]], [[Amiga]] and [[Atari]] and make [[tracker music]], demos and other artwork on them. They were exchanging it using [[floppy disks]], [[FIDOnet]] and later the [[Internet]], so that these artists joined the worldwide demoscene culture. By the year 1995, the first Russian [[demoparty]] occurred, located in St. Petersburg—the second-largest Russian city, situated close to [[Finland]], the country with one of the strongest demoscene cultures.
The demoparty was entitled ENLiGHT; it gathered around 150 people. It was followed by ENLiGHT'96 and ENLiGHT'97; the latter gathered more than 1200 people.
The year 1998 was skipped, and the 1999 festival was held in a new format and under the new name ''Chaos Constructions''.
In 2006 the event's format was shifted closer to a [[LAN party]].
The 2017 festival featured an extra event called ''ChaosConf'' which was aimed at developers and admins of [[Enterprise system|enterprise IT systems]].<ref>{{ru icon}} https://tjournal.ru/59026-istinnyy-kiberpank-kak-ustroen-festival-demosceny-chaos-constructions</ref>
== Present day ==
The 2018 festival was held at a [[coworking|co-working location]] called ''Boiling Point'' and also featured "enterprise" and "telecom" sections. There were several thematic areas; the party went for 2 days without breaking at night.<ref>{{ru icon}} https://www.the-village.ru/village/weekend/events/130055-vyhodnye-v-gorode</ref> [[Twitch.tv]] broadcast it online, and international English-speaking people also participated. The festival's crew also had arranged an "embassy" at a similar earlier gathering called [[Geek Picnic]].<ref>{{ru icon}} https://www.spb.kp.ru/daily/26866/3908980/</ref>

{{Main|List of Christian music festivals|Christian music}} A '''Christian music festival''' (also known as a '''Jesus music festival''' or simply a '''Jesus festival''') is a [[music festival]] held by the [[Christian]] community, in support of performers of [[Contemporary Christian music|Christian music]]. The festivals are characterized by more than just music; many feature motivational speakers and evangelists, and include seminars<ref name="CCM_24_12"/> on Christian spiritual and [[Mission (Christian)|missions]] topics, [[Community service|service]], and [[evangelism]]. They are often viewed as evangelical tools, and small festivals can draw 10 times the crowd of traditional [[revival meetings]].<ref name="TampaT_10-26">{{cite news |first=Martha J. |last=Fry |title=Rock 'N' Roll Revival. |publisher=[[The Tampa Tribune]] |page=4 |date=2002-10-26 }}</ref> While the central theme of a Christian festival is [[Jesus Christ]], the core appeal of a Christian music festival remains the artists and their music.<ref name="CYTY_37_14"/><ref name="Beaujon_2006"/><ref name="Apostles_1999"/> Critics point out that the dichotomy of business and religious interests can be problematic for Christian festivals. In similar ways as the [[Christian music industry]] in general, festivals can be drawn away from their central theme and gravitate toward commercialization and mainstream acts in an attempt to draw crowds.<ref name="CCM_24_12"/><ref name="PRISM_8_3"/><ref name="CYTY_47_7"/><ref name="CSTONE_25_108"/>
[[File:Creation Festival from Lookout.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[Creation Festival]], 2007]] Though Christian music festivals had been held prior to it, 1972 is seen as a pivotal year for Christian music due to the [[Explo '72]] event, which was concluded by a massive music festival. Today Christian music festivals are held regularly throughout the United States and around the world. Christian music festivals were often supported by evangelical organizations; this is still true today, however, there are a number of free-standing festivals as well. Christian festivals are sometimes attached as secondary events to youth conferences, revival meetings, or billed as a part of a weekend package at [[theme park]]s. In 1999 the [[Gospel Music Association]] estimated the commercial revenue of Christian music festivals in the United States at approximately $22 million, with a combined attendance of over one-half million people.<ref name="StarT_6-9"/> Christian music festivals continued to grow significantly into the 2000s, with the number of large festivals rising,<ref name="Sandler06"/> and the formation of a [[Christian festival association|representative organization]] for the festivals themselves.
While [[counter-culture]] is generally accepted many attendees dress conservatively, and unlike their mainstream counterparts Christian music festivals are relatively free of [[Alcoholic beverage|alcohol]] and [[Drug abuse|drug use]].<ref name="CYTY_37_14"/><ref name="StarT_6-9"/><ref name="StLouis_Cstone"/><ref name="ATU_6-8"/><ref name="CYTY_37_51"/><ref name="Baker1980"/> Even at the Explo '72 festival, which was attended by 150,000 or more people, police reported a trouble free event.<ref name="LIFE_72_25"/>
==In the United States==<!-- STOP: This is not a list of Christian Music festivals || This section is for notable festivals with HISTORICAL RELEVANCE || Cite your Sources --> In the early days of the [[Jesus movement|Jesus People movement]] Christian events were sometimes held as part of secular music festivals.<ref name="Baker1980"/><ref name="CYTY_14_6">{{cite journal |last=Taft |first=Adon |title=Preacher in the Mud: Rapping for Christ |journal=[[Christianity Today]] |date=1969-12-19 |volume=14 |issue=6 |page=34 [282] |issn=0009-5753}}</ref> As the genre of [[Jesus music]] gained artists, its followers began to sponsor festivals, mimicking secular events such as [[Woodstock]] and [[Monterey Pop Festival]].<ref name="Apostles_1999">{{cite book |last=Howard |first=Jay R |author2=Streck, John M. |title=Apostles of Rock: The Splintered World of Contemporary Christian Music |year=1999 |publisher=The [[University of Kentucky Press]] |location=[[Lexington, Kentucky|Lexington]], [[Kentucky]] |isbn=0-8131-9086-X |pages=56–59, 151–159}}</ref><ref name="Baker1980"/><ref name="JJT_RBW_2000"/> One of the first events, the [[Youth for Christ]] sponsored Faith Festival, was first held in 1970 in [[Evansville, Indiana]].<ref name="Baker1980"/><ref name="CYTY_15_11"/> The event drew enough attention that the following year it garnered coverage by [[CBS]] and attracted about 15,000.<ref name="Baker1980"/> Artists at the Faith Festival included [[Pat Boone]], [[Gene Cotton]], [[Danny Taylor (musician)|Danny Taylor]], [[Crimson Bridge]], and "e", a band which included [[Greg X. Volz]].<ref name="CCM_10_12"/> The attention that the Faith Festivals drew made them prototypes for future Christian music festivals.<ref name="CCM_4_10">{{cite journal |last=Burns |first=Carolyn A. |date=April 1982 |title=The Past Meets The Present At 1982 Jesus Festivals |journal=[[CCM Magazine]] |volume=4 |issue=10 |pages=71–74 |issn=1524-7848 }}</ref>
Also in 1970, [[Asbury Theological Seminary]] professor Robert Lyon founded the [[Ichthus Music Festival]], which is presently the longest running Christian music festival.<ref name="Apostles_1999"/><ref name="CCM_5_8">{{cite journal |last=Logsdon |first=Kay |date=February 1983 |title=Is There A Festival In Town? |journal=[[CCM Magazine]] |volume=5 |issue=8 |pages=23–27 |issn=1524-7848 }}</ref> ''[[The Hollywood Free Paper]]'', a publication about the Jesus people movement, sponsored festivals in California and other areas of the United States.<ref name="CYTY_15_11">{{cite journal |last=Plowman |first=Edward E. |title=Taking Stock of Jesus Rock |date=February 1971 |journal=[[Christianity Today]] |volume=15 |issue=11 |pages=32–33 |issn=0009-5753}}</ref><ref name="CYTY_15_22"/> In 1971 the "Love Song Festival", sponsored by [[Maranatha! Music]], was held at [[Knott's Berry Farm]].<ref name="Baker1980"/> Attendance was reported to be 20,000, a park record at the time, and artists included [[Love Song (band)|Love Song]], [[The Way (band)|The Way]], [[Blessed Hope]], and the [[Children of the Day]].<ref name="CCM_10_12">{{cite journal |last=Baker |first=Paul |date=June 1988 |title=It's A Festival |journal=[[CCM Magazine]] |volume=10 |issue=12 |page=24 |issn=1524-7848 }}</ref> In late 1971 ''Christianity Today'' summarized four festivals that had taken place during the summer season.<ref name="CYTY_15_22">{{cite journal |last=Eggebroten |first=Anne |title=Jesus Festivals |journal=[[Christianity Today]] |date=1971-08-06 |volume=15 |issue=22 |pages=38–40 |issn=0009-5753}}</ref> The same article described the artists who appeared at a [[Santa Barbara, California]] event, including [[Gentle Faith]], [[Tom Howard (musician)|Tom Howard]], Ron Salsbury, The Bridge, and [[Randy Stonehill]], as being "veterans of Jesus rock festivals".<ref name="CYTY_15_22"/>
1972 is seen as a pivotal year for Christian music festivals due to a [[Revival meeting|crusade]] and [[evangelism]] training event called [[Explo '72]], held in [[Dallas, Texas]]. Explo was sponsored by the World Conference on Missions and [[Campus Crusade for Christ]].<ref name="PRISM_8_3"/> The week-long event was attended by 80,000 registered attendees and concluded with a day-long music festival. The attendance of the final event was reported by ''Life'' magazine at 150,000<ref>For more reported attendance figures, see talk page.</ref> and was characteristic by [[Billy Graham]] as a "religious [[Woodstock]]."<ref name="LIFE_72_25">{{cite journal |date=1972-06-30 |title=Rallying For Jesus; 80,000 jam Dallas for a crusade called Explo '72 |journal=[[Life (magazine)|Life]] |volume=72 |issue=25 |pages=40–45 |issn=0024-3019 }}</ref><ref name="Powell_Fe_GEN">{{cite book |last=Powell |first=Mark Allan |title=Encyclopedia of Contemporary Christian Music |year=2002 |publisher=Hendrickson Publishers |location=[[Peabody, Massachusetts|Peabody]], [[Massachusetts]] |isbn=1-56563-679-1 |edition=First printing}}</ref> The Explo '72 roster contained artists in a variety of genres including performers [[Larry Norman]], Love Song, [[Andrae Crouch]], and [[Johnny Cash]]. Explo '72 was a watershed event for the fledgling Jesus Music genre, and was the most visible event of the Jesus People movement.<ref name="Sabatino_1999">{{cite book |last=Sabatino |first=David Di |title=The Jesus People Movement: An Annotated Bibliography and General Resource |series=Bibliographies and Indexes in Religious Studies |volume=49 |year=1999 |publisher=Greenwood Press |location=[[Westport, CT]] |isbn=0-313-30268-5 |pages=16–17 |chapter=The Spiritual Sixties and the Jesus People Movement }}</ref> It is also the largest Christian music festival ever recorded;<ref name="Baker1980"/> some critics even credit Explo with jump-starting the Christian music industry.<ref name="PRISM_8_3"/><ref name="JJT_RBW_2000"/>
Early Christian music festivals were noted for their conservatism, often limiting their [[artistic expression]] to "safe, [[Middle of the road (music)#Contemporary usage|middle-of-the-road]] acts."<ref name="CSTONE_25_108"/> The [[Jesus Festival]], which was founded in 1973, offers a few illustrative incidents. In their inaugural year they hired a promoter, Tim Landis, who brought in acts such as [[2nd Chapter of Acts]], [[Pat Terry (musician)|Pat Terry]], and [[Phil Keaggy]]. The conservative owners, who wanted a [[family oriented]] music festival, found the music "a little too racy" and fired him.<ref name="CCM_24_12">{{cite journal |last=Nentwig |first=Wendy Lee |date=June 2002 |title=GODapalooza |journal=[[CCM Magazine]] |volume=24 |issue=12 |pages=42–46 |issn=1524-7848 }}</ref> The following year at the same festival, [[Randy Matthews]] was chased off stage by a crowd which pronounced him to be [[Demonic possession|demon]] or [[Drug abuse|drug]] possessed due to his musical style and his announcement of an impending tour with [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] and [[ZZ Top]].<ref name="Powell_Fe_RM">{{cite book |last=Powell |title=Encyclopedia of Contemporary Christian Music |year=2002 |chapter=Randy Matthews |pages=566–569}}</ref> Matthews was later dropped from the tour roster.
{{Christian music festivals in 1975|nolabels=1|width=300|float=left}} The number and size of Christian music festivals continued to grow alongside the Christian music industry. By the mid 1970s festivals had appeared in all parts of the country.<ref name="Baker1980">{{cite book |last1=Baker |first1=Paul |title=Why Should The Devil Have All The Good Music? |edition=2nd printing |date=December 1980 |origyear=1971 |publisher= |location= |isbn=0-8499-2858-3 |pages=27, 145–153 |chapter=12. All Day Diner}}</ref> Tim Landis went on to found the [[Creation Festival]] in 1979, which was designed to appeal the youth,<ref name="CCM_5_8"/> and has become one of the largest Christian festivals in the United States. For several years Creation was held at the same venue as the Jesus Festival, the Agape Farm, only a few weeks apart.<ref name="CCM_24_12"/> More specialized festivals appeared to fill [[niche market]]s within the industry. The first completely rock music oriented festival was held in 1981.<ref name="CCM_4_1">{{cite journal |last=Donaldson |first=Devlin |date=July 1981 |title=Illinois Jam: An Oasis in The Midwest |journal=[[CCM Magazine]] |volume=4 |issue=1 |pages=51 |issn=1524-7848 }}</ref><ref name="CCM_4_4">{{cite journal |last=Donaldson |first=Devlin |date=October 1981 |title=How Illinois' First Rock Fest Got Into A Jam |journal=[[CCM Magazine]] |volume=4 |issue=4 |pages=52–53 |issn=1524-7848 }}</ref> Called Illinois Jam, it featured artists including [[Barnabas (band)|Barnabas]], [[Servant (band)|Servant]], [[Avion (band)|Randall Waller]], and Randy Stonehill. [[Christian metal]] festivals also emerged, particularly in the late 1980s. One such festival was held in [[Carson, California]] in September 1987.<ref name="CCM_10_5">{{cite journal |last=Van Pelt |first=Doug |authorlink=Doug Van Pelt |date=November 1988 |title=Metal to Test Your Mettle |journal=[[CCM Magazine]] |volume=10 |issue=15 |page=38 |issn=1524-7848 }}</ref> The lineup was entirely Christian metal bands and included [[Guardian (band)|Guardian]], [[Barren Cross]], [[Vengeance Rising]], and many smaller bands.<ref name="CCM_10_5"/>
[[File:Cornerstone Festival.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Cornerstone main stage, 2007]] While the members of [[Jesus People USA]] had long been involved in Christian festivals around the country,<ref name="CYTY_47_7"/><ref name="CSTONE_25_108"/> the [[Chicago]] organization founded the [[Cornerstone Festival]] in 1984. Seeing the trend toward conservatism, Cornerstone was designed to set itself apart by being artistically unrestrictive.<ref name="Beaujon_2006">{{cite book |last=Beaujon |first=Andrew |title=Body Piercing Saved My Life: Inside the Phenomenon of Christian Rock |url=http://www.bodypiercingsavedmylife.com/ |year=2006 |publisher=Da Capo Press |location=[[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], [[Massachusetts]] |isbn=0-306-81457-9 |pages=13–17 }}</ref> Its design came from the counter-culture of JPUSA itself, with an intent to appeal to an audience that may not have been attracted to more conservative forms of music.<ref name="CYTY_47_7">{{cite journal |title=Jesus' Woodstock: after 20 summers of love, the Cornerstone Festival still opens doors for unknown musicians and unlocks truth for hungry minds |last=Hertz |first=Todd |author2=Eric Pulliam |date=July 2003 |journal=[[Christianity Today]] |volume=47 |issue=7 |pages=46–54 |issn=0009-5753 |url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2003/july/5.46.html}}</ref> As ''[[Cornerstone (magazine)|Cornerstone]]'' magazine editor Jon Trott later characterized it: "Cornerstone would be to Jesus festivals what [[Seven Up]] was to [[cola]]: the ''unfestival''."<ref name="CSTONE_25_108"/> Their slogan in 1984 was "More Rock And Roll Than Anyone Has Dared";<ref name="CSTONE_25_108"/><!-- PARTIAL LIST designed to show the variety of bands which played at the first CSTONE --> Artists included [[Kerry Livgren]], [[Resurrection Band]], [[The Choir (alternative rock band)|The Choir]], [[Joe English (musician)|Joe English]], and the [[Sweet Comfort Band]].<ref name="CSTONE_25_108">{{cite journal |last=Trott |first=Jon |year=1996 |title=Life's Lessons: The History of Jesus People USA Part Six |journal=[[Cornerstone (magazine)|Cornerstone]] |publisher=[[Jesus People USA]] |issn=0275-2743 |volume=25 |issue=108 |pages=47–48 |url=http://www.jpusa.org/lessons6.html }}</ref> Cornerstone was one of the premier Christian music festivals,<ref name="Beaujon_2006"/><ref name="PRISM_8_3">{{cite journal |last=Thompson |first=John J. |authorlink=John J. Thompson |year=2001 |title=By the Time We Got to Woodstock... Christians, Rock and Roll, and Summer Music Festivals |journal=Prism |publisher=[[Evangelicals for Social Action]] |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=30–31 |issn=1079-6479 }}</ref> and was most influential promoting groups on the fringe of Christian music.<ref name="JJT_RBW_2000"/> The last Cornerstone Festival was held in 2012, citing the difficult economy.<ref>[http://www.cornerstonefestival.com/information/specialAnnouncement.php A Special Announcement From Cornerstone Festival] Cornerstonefestival.com. 2011-07-02. Retrieved 2013-09-21</ref>
In the 1990s the contemporary Christian music industry experienced explosive growth and saw the establishment of new festivals as well.<ref name="JJT_RBW_2000"/> The most significant of these are Purple Door and [[Tomfest]], the latter of which regularly holds mini-festivals in diverse parts of the country.<ref name="JJT_RBW_2000">{{cite book |last=Thompson |first=John J. |authorlink=John J. Thompson |title=Raised by Wolves |year=2000 |publisher=ECW Press |isbn=978-1-55022-421-4 |pages=79, 147–151, 234}}</ref> Since the turn of the century traveling tours such as [[Festival Con Dios]] and [[Shout Fest]] have appeared. They are often similar in structure to their secular counterparts such as [[Vans Warped Tour]] or [[Lolapalooza]], offering [[extreme sports]] and a carnival-like atmosphere.<ref name="TampaT_10-26"/><ref name="GazCS_6-8">{{cite news |first=Jen |last=Mulson |title=Godapalooza; Festival fuses Christian music with extreme sports |publisher=[[The Gazette (Colorado Springs)|The Gazette]] |page=GO 14 |date=2001-06-08 }}</ref> Throughout the 2000s, the attendance at United States festivals grew significantly. According to one source, the number of Christian music festivals attended by more than 5000 youths grew from five in the year 2000 to 35 in 2006.<ref name="Sandler06">{{cite book |last=Sandler |first=Lauren |title=Righteous: Dispatches from the Evangelical Youth Movement |year=2006 |publisher=[[Penguin Group]] |location=New York |isbn=0-670-03791-5 |chapter=You Will Know Them By Their Numbers}}</ref> As a result of this growth, many US festivals have formed a collective organization, the [[Christian Festival Association]], to represent their interests.
[[LifeLight Communications]] started an annual [[LifeLight Music Festival]] in 1998 which now occurs over [[Labor Day]] weekend on farmland near [[Worthing, South Dakota]].<ref>Reinecke, Sarah. Lifelight attendance probably a record, financial goal close.'' Argus Leader''. Sioux Falls, S.D.: Sep 8, 2010.</ref>
==Worldwide== [[File:EO Jongerendag 2004.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[EO Youth Day]] in the Netherlands]] Christian music festivals now exist throughout the world. The [[Greenbelt festival]], founded in 1974 in the United Kingdom, was at one time one of the largest recurring Christian event in the world.<ref name="CCM_6_5">{{cite journal |last=Nelles |first=Wendy Elaine |date=November 1983 |title=Greenbelt Breaks Record |journal=[[CCM Magazine]] |volume=6 |issue=5 |pages=54–57 |issn=1524-7848 }}</ref> Germany is host to several festivals; four of the most notable are [[Christmas Rock Night]], [[Freakstock]], Himmelfahrt-Festival and Rock Without Limits.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} In greater Europe notable festivals include [[Flevo Festival|Flevo]] and EO-Youth Day in the Netherlands,{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} Seaside Festival in Norway,{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} the [[Big Boss' Festival]] in Switzerland,{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} the Song of Songs Festival in Poland,{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} Festival Lumen in Slovakia and Frizon Festival in Sweden.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} In 2014 the first Christian music festival is being held in Hungary (named Cross Sound).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://crosssound.hu/en/info/a-fesztivalrol|title=CrossSound Összművészeti Fesztivál|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2017}}</ref>{{Better source|date=May 2014|reason=a secondary source to show it's notable.}}
A [[Religion in the Soviet Union|sanctioned]] Christian festival was held in 1989 in [[Tallinn]], [[Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic|Soviet Estonia]].<ref name="CCM_12_11">{{cite journal |last=Geisler |first=Dave |date=June 1990 |title=Musicianaries For Christ |journal=[[CCM Magazine]] |volume=12 |issue=11 |pages=22–23, 26, 28 |issn=1524-7848 }}</ref> The festival featured performances by American artists such as [[Sheila Walsh (singer)|Sheila Walsh]], [[Bruce Carroll]], [[Paul Smith (Christian music)|Paul Smith]], and [[Scott Wesley Brown]], and had an attendance of 15,000.<ref name="CCM_12_11"/> This was reported to be the first such festival. In 1992, after the [[Revolutions of 1989|Fall of the Iron Curtain]], a Christian music festival was held in [[St. Petersburg, Russia|St. Petersburg]], [[Russia]].<ref name="CCM_14_9"/> Dubbed as a "Christian arts festival", the event included acts to appeal to all ages from a variety of styles, largely representing greater Europe and North America. The event also included orchestras from the UK and Russia, and Russian headliner [[Boris Grebenshchikov]]. The shows, which were organized by [[Youth With A Mission]], sold out 10,000 tickets well in advance.<ref name="CCM_14_9">{{cite journal |last=Van Pelt |first=Doug |authorlink=Doug Van Pelt |date=March 1992 |title=Artists Ignite Sacred Fire In Hearts of Russians |journal=[[CCM Magazine]] |volume=14 |issue=9 |page=13 |issn=1524-7848 }}</ref>
From 1992–2014, New Zealand hosted the Southern Hemisphere's largest Christian festival, the annual [[Parachute Music Festival]]. It attracted a large number of non-Christians.
In Brazil, in the city of [[Fortaleza]], [[Ceará]] annually happens Halleluya Festival, which brings together music from the various attractions theatrical performances and dance. Is among the largest Catholic music festivals in the world, and in its latest edition the record crowd of 300,000 people in one day, and more than 1 million people over the five days of the Festival. The event is held by [[Catholic Community Shalom]]. The Halleluya Festival has editions in several Brazilian cities such as [[Brasília]], [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[São Paulo]], and also outside the country as in [[Rome]]. {{Expand section|examples and additional citations|date=December 2008}}

{{Infobox NRHP | nrhp_type = nrhp | nrhp_type2 = cp | nocat = yes | designated_nrhp_type2 = December 24, 2009 | partof = Biddeford Main Street Historic District | partof_refnum = 09001146 | image = Biddeford_Maine_City_Hall.jpg | caption = City Hall complex containing the theater | location= 205 Main St., [[Biddeford, Maine]] | coordinates = {{coord|43|29|36|N|70|27|26|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Maine#USA | built = {{Start date|1895}} | architect = [[John Calvin Stevens]] | added = April 24, 1973 | area = less than one acre | governing_body = Local | refnum = 73000156<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> }} Biddeford '''City Theater''' is a restored Victorian [[opera house]] at 205 Main Street in [[Biddeford, Maine|Biddeford]], [[Maine]], [[United States]]. City Theater produces and hosts theater, dance and music performances year-round and aims to, “foster an appreciation for the performing arts by using creative avenues to increase community involvement.”<ref>[http://citytheater.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=13&Itemid=29 Biddeford’s City Theater: Board of Directors]</ref>
City Theater is part of the '''Biddeford City Hall''' complex, designed by Maine architect [[John Calvin Stevens]] in 1895. The building is included on the [[National Register of Historic Places]],<ref name="nombldg">{{cite web| url = {{NRHP url|id=73000156}}| title = National Register of Historic Places Nomination Form: Biddeford City Hall| accessdate = 2014-12-24|author= Richard D. Kelly, Jr.| format = PDF| publisher=[[National Park Service]]|date= February 1973}} {{NRHP url|id=73000156|title=Photos|photos=y}}</ref> and is a contributing element to the [[Biddeford Main Street Historic District]].<ref name="nomhd">{{cite web| url = {{NRHP url|id=09001146}}| title = National Register of Historic Places Registration Form: Biddeford Main Street Historic District| accessdate = 2014-12-24|author= Shauna J. Haas| format = PDF| publisher=[[National Park Service]]|date= August 20, 2009}} {{NRHP url|id=09001146|title=Photos|photos=y}}</ref>
==Theater history== Biddeford's City Theater originally opened as an opera house in October 1860 at its present Main Street location as a part of the Biddeford City Hall complex. The opera house enjoyed a high level of popularity in the Biddeford and Southern Maine region until burning down December 30, 1894. Whether to rebuild the opera house was debated, the city eventually settled on rebuilding a more structurally sound opera house.<ref name="Biddeford City Theater: History">[http://citytheater.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=16&Itemid=34 Biddeford City Theater: History]</ref>
Architect John Calvin Stevens was chosen to design the new city hall and opera house, which opened January 20, 1896. The opera house again became a favorite site for cultural and entertainment attractions. Through to the 1920s it brought [[vaudeville]], [[minstrel shows]], illustrated songs, dramatic performances and even community pageants and plays to the Southern Maine community.<ref name="Biddeford City Theater: History"/>
The introduction of [[talkies]] in 1928 began the transition from opera house to movie theater. In 1955, “improvements” to its interior were made, including panelling of the lobby and its staircase and addition poster displays and a [[cinemascope]] screen. The name of the opera house was at this time officially changed to Biddeford's City Theater.<ref name="Biddeford City Theater: History"/>
However, with the increased popularity of [[drive-ins]] and television, City Theater had closed its doors by 1963 and remained closed until 1978. In the interim, Biddeford's City Theater was used as a storage facility for the city and, at one point, a horse-shoe pit, complete with a pile of sand dumped in the orchestra pit. Ironically, also during this period, in 1973 Biddeford's City Theater was added to the National Register of Historical Places.<ref name="Biddeford City Theater: History"/>
In 1977, the newly incorporated City Theater Associates launched a campaign to renovate and re-open the opera house. Thus, a year later, the internationally popular [[Norman Luboff Choir]] opened for Biddeford's City Theater's first performance season in nearly 50 years.<ref name="Biddeford City Theater: History"/>
Though great improvements were made to its interior during the re-opening, City Theater was still in great need of restoration. It was not until the 1990s, when City Theater celebrated its centennial, that the theater received a full restoration. Funding was provided by local, state and federal governments along with private donations from local businesses and individuals. A new marquee, re-stenciling of the lobby and house walls and ceilings and new sound and lighting were among the improvements made.<ref name="Biddeford City Theater: History"/>
==Present day==
Current renovations to Biddeford's City Theater include re-pointing the exterior brickwork and improving the stage floor and restrooms.{{update after|2015|5|2}}
City Theater currently runs a year-round season of theater, music and dance performances. Additionally, the theater has recently added community theater and youth opera and developed an ongoing relationship with the [[University of New England (United States)|University of New England]].<ref name="Biddeford City Theater: History"/>

'''Clothing scam companies''' are companies or [[gangs]] that purport to be collecting [[Used goods|second-hand]] clothes for [[Charitable organization|charities]] or to be working for charitable causes, when they are in fact working for themselves, giving little if anything to charitable causes. They are a particular problem in the [[United Kingdom|UK]], where they rely on people's awareness of proper charities established practise of collecting used clothes for good causes. These companies cause major problems for established charities in terms of lost [[donations]] and making the public distrustful of all clothes collectors.
== Advertising ==
A popular tactic of clothing scam companies is to leaflet a particular area and then move on before people become aware that the company is a clothing scam company. These leaflets will often illegally claim that they are either charities or working for established charities. Often they will state in [[small print]] that they are a commercial company, but will prominently place wording that implies they are, often quoting very vague charitable aims such as 'third world collection' etc.
These companies are very difficult to prosecute as frequently they are not in fact companies at all, quoting fictitious company names or someone else's company name, when in fact they are just a gang of people getting together to resell used-clothes. Many clothing scam companies use casual labour to deliver the leaflets and collect bags of clothing. They are not officially employed by the clothing scam company, which doesn't keep a record of the people they use that can be checked.
